title: Why in years past was it so common for entertainers to 'mug' for the camera, making silly and contorted faces, while this is something you rarely see today? - Quora

response.answer_text: A2A. I’m sure there are other reasons, but I would point to the influence of live theater and vaudeville. When cinema was first invented, the American industry was centered in NYC; Broadway and vaudeville actors were hired to perform for the camera. They were used to broad gestures and facial expressions because “big” acting was visible to spectators throughout a large, live venue. Since cinema was originally silent, broad gestures also helped to substitute for non-existent dialogue: movie acting was essentially a form of pantomime. This influence continued when talkies were invented and even through the early years of television. (Think of Lucille Ball’s “Waaaaaaaaaaa” whenever Ricky caught on to her schemes, or Jackie Gleason’s big “To the moon, Alice, to the moon!”) Eventually, however, filmmakers realized that with a 40′ high screen, faces were big enough they didn’t require mugging to make a comic point. And all acting became more “realistic”, since cinema was the most influential art form of the 20th century. One still sees a certain amount of mugging on TV, particularly from children in cheesy sitcoms, but on the whole the style has been dropped as too over-the-top for filmed media. Not everyone considers the evolution I’ve described a positive one. Some people find more artistry in the formalist mugging of the Three Stooges or Marx Brothers. They are less amused by the supposedly witty remarks on which sitcoms are based today.

I suppose in the acting industry nowadays it’s a lot more serious. I remember starting a few years ago, and ‘mugging’ for the camera was something we found absolutely hilarious and fun. It’s sort of like purposely making bloopers. It was really fun to do with your fellow cast. Nowadays, I feel like the industry’s evolved to become very serious, and most actors (even A-list ones) just come to film, chat a bit and then head home - it’s just their job to earn money, and they’re not sticking around ‘mugging’ a camera. Though, I’m not going to lie, I miss the old days!
